title: Big, Strong and, now, Compliant.
article: Big, Strong and, now, Compliant. Microdrones md4-3000 added to Transport Canada Listing of Compliant UAVs VAUDREUIL-DORION, Quebec, June 12, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Microdrones md4-3000 has been added to Transport Canada's (TC) exclusive list of compliant unmanned aerial vehicles. To date, only fifteen manufacturers worldwide have achieved this distinction. Vivien Heriard-Dubreuil, president of Microdrones, explained why this is important, not only in Canada, but internationally. "Professionals across all continents view Transport Canada compliance as a benchmark for aviation safety, quality, consistency and reliability. At Microdrones, we design and build our integrated solutions around the needs of demanding commercial users; the aircraft is the backbone of our offering, enabling long, safe flight times, and resistance to harsh conditions." Sebastien Long, sales manager for Microdrones in Canada added, "Last year our md4-1000 aircraft achieved Transport Canada compliance. Adding the md4-3000 to this list provides my customers in Canada with more options for heavier sensors; our md4-3000 can carry payloads up to 5kg/11lbs." Recognized as having one of the safest, most successful civil aviation programs in the world, Canada's admirable record is largely attributed to the efforts of Transport Canada. The organization works diligently with domestic and international partners to maintain a pristine safety and security record. Microdrones was required to submit detailed application materials, including flight, maintenance, and design manuals in order to achieve Transport Canada compliance. Microdrones Flight Operations and Production Manager, Jocelyne Bois said "Selecting a compliant UAV enables professionals to apply for a Compliant Operator Certificate from Transport Canada. This will give them additional privileges and is prerequisite to flying Beyond Visual Line of Sight. That's increasingly going to be an important distinction for professional drone geomatics work." Transport Canada compliant operators may be granted greater geographic flexibility, like flying in restricted areas, closer to airports or cities, and beyond the visual line of sight. They may also benefit from extended validity, streamlined renewal, and priority processing of Special Flight Operations Certificates (SFOC). Mike Hogan, sales director for Microdrones explained, "This is an important step in our development as the world leader in professional unmanned systems. Microdrones developed the world's first commercial quadcopter more than ten years ago and today our mdMapper, mdLiDAR and mdTector solutions lead the industry for aerial surveying via photogrammetry and LiDAR, as well as methane gas detection." Interested in making a Transport Canada compliant system a part of your workflow? Please contact us! About Microdrones Founded in Germany in 2005, Microdrones developed the world's first commercial quadcopter and the company continues to lead the industry with their professional UAV solutions. By pairing robust drones with cutting-edge sensors, Microdrones offers advanced turn-key solutions that make it easy for businesses to start using UAVs for surveying, mapping, construction, inspection, precision agriculture, mining, and other commercial applications. A heritage of quality German engineering, extra-long flight times, resistance to environmental challenges, and technology like direct georeferencing make Microdrones solutions exceptionally safe, efficient, and cost-effective choices for commercial users. Contact: Mike Dziok Marketing Director Microdrones news@microdrones.com (END)

title: MHC Match Capital to acquire Braingrid as QT
article: Match Capital Resources Corp (TSX-V:MHC) Shares Issued 8,615,445 Thursday June 07 2018 - News Release Mr. Nadim Wakeam reports MATCH CAPITAL RESOURCES CORPORATION ENTERS INTO LETTER OF INTENT TO BRAINGRID CORPORATION Match Capital Resources Corp. has entered into a letter of intent dated June 4, 2018, with Braingrid Corp., a private precision agriculture company focused on the cannabis sector, to acquire all the issued and outstanding securities of Braingrid. The transaction is subject to TSX Venture Exchange approval and applicable shareholder and regulatory approvals as set forth in more detail below. It is intended that the transaction will be completed by way of a three-cornered amalgamation of Braingrid, Match and a wholly owned subsidiary of Match (Match Subco) to form a new company (Amalco), provided, however that, by mutual agreement, the parties may revise the structure to comply with all necessary legal and regulatory requirements, to minimize or eliminate any adverse tax consequences or to increase cost-effectiveness. The transaction is intended to result in a reverse takeover of Match by Braingrid's shareholders. Terms of the agreement Subject to the satisfaction of the conditions to closing, on or prior to the closing of the transaction, Match Subco will amalgamate with Braingrid to form Amalco, and Match will issue postconsolidated common shares of Match to the shareholders of Braingrid, in consideration for the transfer of their Braingrid common shares to Match, on the basis that each common share held by shareholders of Braingrid will be exchanged for two postconsolidation common shares of Match resulting in Amalco becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Match. The transaction will be an arm's-length transaction for Match. Upon the closing of the transaction, Match will be renamed Braingrid Ltd. or such other name as the parties agree to. Match and Braingrid have agreed to use all commercially reasonable efforts to close the transaction prior to Sept. 10, 2018. The LOI will terminate in the event the parties fail to enter into a definitive amalgamation agreement on or prior to June 22, 2018, unless a later date is otherwise mutually agreed to by the parties. Capitalization As of the date hereof, Match has 8,615,445 common shares issued and outstanding and a maximum of $365,000 of accounts payable, accrued liabilities and amounts due to shareholders, of which approximately $345,000 will be converted into common shares of Match at a posttransaction value of 40 cents per share, subject to regulatory approval. Under the terms of the LOI, Match will consolidate all of its issued and outstanding securities on a one-for-eight basis (or such other ratio as may be required by TSX Venture Exchange policies) and convert its outstanding debt into equity at a postconsolidation share price of 40 cents per Match common share, subject to receipt of required regulatory and shareholder approval. Prior to the closing of the transaction, subsequent to the consolidation and debt conversion, Match will have no more than two million postconsolidation shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis, excluding shares and warrants issued in connection with the financing (as defined below). Prior to the closing of the transaction, Braingrid will have no more than 32 million shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis, excluding shares and warrants issued in connection with the financing. Assuming $3-million is raised pursuant to the financing, on a posttransaction basis, Match will have 48,851,357 common shares issued and outstanding on an undiluted basis and 72,497,096 on a fully diluted basis. The existing shareholders of Braingrid will hold approximately 73.24 per cent of the issued and outstanding fully diluted consolidated common shares of the resulting issuer. Match shareholders will own approximately 2.68 per cent of the issued and outstanding fully diluted consolidated common shares of the resulting issuer. Braingrid's advisers pursuant to the transaction, 514 Financial Inc. and Harris Capital Corp., will own approximately 2.56 per cent of the issued and outstanding fully diluted consolidated common shares of the resulting issuer. Finders will own approximately 0.82 per cent of the issued and outstanding fully diluted consolidated common shares of the resulting issuer. Investors in the financing will own approximately 20.70 per cent of the issued and outstanding fully diluted consolidated common shares of the resulting issuer. Conditions of closing The closing of the transaction is subject to several conditions, including, among other things: (i) receipt of all regulatory approvals, including that of the TSX-V; (ii) requisite corporate approval of the various transactions contemplated by the transaction from the directors and shareholders of Match and Braingrid, as applicable; (iii) closing of the financing, as described below; and (iv) approval by the securityholders of Match of the proposed name change, the consolidation of its outstanding shares on a one-for-eight basis, the shares-for-debt settlement terms, and the share issuances to the shareholders of Braingrid, specifically the deemed price at which such debt will be settled and shares will be issued being 40 cents per share on a postconsolidation basis. Financing Prior to the closing of the transaction, Braingrid is required to have completed a non-brokered private placement to raise gross proceeds of up to $3-million at a price of 80 cents per security. The financing will consist of a private placement of units of Braingrid, each unit consisting of one common share of Braingrid and one common share purchase warrant, each warrant entitling the holder to purchase one common share at a price of $1 per share for a period of 24 months from the closing date of the financing. The proceeds of the financing will be used to finance capital expenditures, mergers and acquisitions, working capital, and general corporate purposes. In connection with the financing, certain finders, including EMD Financial Inc., will receive a cash commission of 8 per cent of the gross proceeds of the financing and warrants entitling the finder to purchase that number of common shares of Braingrid as is equal to 4 per cent of the number of units of Braingrid issued to purchasers introduced to Braingrid by the finder under the financing, exercisable at a price of $1, for a period of 24 months from the closing of the financing. The finder will also receive a number of common shares of Braingrid equal to 4 per cent of the number of units issued to purchasers introduced to Braingrid by the finder under the financing. Business of Braingrid Braingrid is a Canadian-controlled private corporation based in Toronto, Ont. It was incorporated federally in Canada in 2012. Braingrid is a precision agriculture technology company that provides an affordable, versatile and quick-to-install global sensor platform that captures the critical real-time data needed by licensed cannabis producers to increase revenues, reduce costs and reduce risks. Braingrid has commercialized a proprietary device called the Sentroller, which, in the case of cannabis, is installed in licensed medical cannabis facilities. These Sentrollers connect to sensors, which measure environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity and carbon dioxide. These data are communicated wirelessly to a Braingrid gateway in the facility, which in turn sends the data through cellular modem to Internet-based servers. These data can then be accessed by customers through on-line dashboards and reports. In addition, the platform can send e-mail alarms to the customer when out-of-bounds conditions are sensed. The company has business agreements with Ample Organics Inc., WeedMD Inc., Beleave Kannabis Corp. and R2G Global LLC to develop and deploy its technology. For the 12-month period ended March 31, 2018, Braingrid had net sales of approximately $157,000 (unaudited) and a net loss of approximately $667,000 (unaudited). As at March 31, 2018, Braingrid had total assets of approximately $1.8-million (unaudited), including cash of approximately $1.6-million (unaudited) and shareholders' equity of approximately $1.7-million (unaudited). The major shareholders of Braingrid are the founder Michael Kadonoff of Toronto, Ont., who holds 27 per cent indirectly of Braingrid's current issued and outstanding common shares, and Kenneth Kadonoff of Toronto, Ont., who owns 27 per cent directly and indirectly of Braingrid's current issued and outstanding common shares. The resulting issuer Match and Braingrid have agreed that upon the closing date, the board of directors of the resulting issuer shall consist of five directors to be appointed by Braingrid. Such appointments are subject to the approval of the TSX-V. The names and backgrounds of each of these persons will be published in a later press release. Management of the resulting issuer after the qualifying transaction It is expected that management of the resulting issuer will be as follows. Michael Kadonoff, founder and chief executive officer Prior to founding Braingrid in 2012, Michael worked as a professional hardware designer at GE Grid IQ on the premier design team for energy grid automation and control products. Michael is an avid inventor and a passionate energy reform visionary. Michael has a BEng from McMaster University and a technologist diploma in electrical and electronics engineering from Lakehead University. Matthew Skynner, president and chief operating officer Mr. Skynner has over 25 years of high-tech experience, including leading a global $1-billion technology business as corporate vice-president and general manager at AMD. He spent 17 years in various roles at AMD (previously ATI), including vice-president, corporate marketing; vice-president, product marketing; and corporate vice-president and general manager of the graphics business unit. He gained deep experience with sensing, control and automation systems during his 10-year tenure at Honeywell Ltd. He has also served on the board of directors of the IT Association of Canada. He is a professional engineer and holds a bachelor of science in electrical engineering and an MBA from the University of Manitoba. Kenneth Kadonoff, executive chairman Kenneth is a nimble, hands-on leader in business development, problem solving, legal work and interim management in a variety of industries. He practised commercial law with top Toronto law firms since 1978, then transitioned to chief operating officer for a Toronto Stock Exchange-listed company and was vice-chairman of the Canadian Franchise Association. He has deep-established network relationships and business and legal experience across many industries. He holds a BComm from Concordia University (Montreal) and BCL and LLB. degrees from McGill University (Montreal). Doug Harris, chief financial officer Mr. Harris is a chartered accountant and a chartered business valuator with over 20 years of experience in the financial service sector, including accounting, operations, corporate finance, equity research, private equity, and mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Harris has a BSc in physical geography from the University of Guelph and an MBA (accounting) from the University of Toronto, Rotman School of Management. Sponsorship and valuation A sponsorship and valuation may be required by the TSX-V in connection with the transaction unless exemptions from the sponsorship and valuation requirements are available. Match intends to apply for an exemption from the sponsorship and valuation requirements. There is no assurance that Match will be able to obtain such an exemption. Trading halt Match's common shares are currently halted, and Match anticipates they will remain halted until the completion of the transaction.

title: Chemicals - North America
article: Current Environment - US Sector Overview US chemical industry growth continued over the six months under review despite a strong dollar and weaknesses in the global economy. Growth was due mainly to a strengthening domestic economy, increasing consumer spending and encouraging data from key end-user markets, particularly light vehicles and housing. US chemical exports by sea rose by 2.1% to 992,063 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in 2017, from 819,887 TEUs in 2016, the biggest growth since 2014, despite stricter regulation and trade disputes with China, which was the biggest importer of US chemicals by sea, followed by Belgium and Japan. According to he American Chemistry Council (ACC), US chemicals exports worth US$173 billion were the second biggest globally in 2017, after Germany's US$234.6 billion and China's of US$152.4 billon, US ethylene production used to be among the world's most expensive. Thanks to shale revolution it now can produce cheap ethane extracted from shale gas, and is now a global petrochemical leader. Specialty chemical market volume rose by 0.9% year on year in April 2018, according to the ACC's US Specialty Chemicals Market Volume Index, which observes 28 specialty chemical segments. Of the 28, there was growth in 24, a decline in one, while the other and three were static. The index increased by 4.7% from a year earlier in the first four months of 2018. Revenues and profits of four out of five leading chemical companies grew in first quarter 2018, the exception being Monsanto. The rises were to operational efficiency and robust demand for chemical products in domestic and international markets. Joint venture and merger and acquisition (M&A) activities continued to grow in the five months through May 2018, led by growth initiatives and active fund managers. Hurricane Harvey ravaged the Texas Gulf Coast, affecting more than half of its chemical plants, including refineries and specialty chemical facilities. Harvey caused the Arkema plant to explode, shutting down more than half of US ethylene production and recovery took months. In May 2018, the US Chemical Safety Board insisted that chemical producers devise better plans to avoid such outages during severe weather. The industry is crucial to the US economy as the Texas Gulf Coast is the heart of America's specialty and petrochemicals industry. Sector Performance Share prices of the eight leading US chemical companies were rose by an average 0.28% over the six months through June 1, 2018, underperforming the S&P 500 Index's 1.69% increase. The eight leading companies' share prices were mixed, with Eastman Chemical (NYSE: EMN) having the highest and only double digit share price growth. Its share price rose by 12.88%, from US$93.71to US$105.78, due to good financials, increased specialty demand and better cost management bringing a double-digit rise in earnings per share. One of the biggest agrochemical firms Monsanto's (NYSE: MON) share price rose by 9.49%, from US$116.50 to US$127.56, following US justice Department approval of its merger with German multinational company Bayer (ETR: BAYN) in April 2018. North and South America's largest industrial gases company Praxair's (NYSE: PX) share price has risen since it announced that it would buy the world's largest industrial gas company Linde AG (ETR: LIN) in October 2017. The deal will increase its presence in Germany and make Praxair the world's biggest industrial gas company and sent Praxair's share price up from US$155.15 to US$157.80. One of the world's largest chemical companies LyondellBasell's (NYSE: LYB) good first quarter 2018, combined with its February announcement that it would acquire leading global supplier of high-performance plastic compounds A. Schulman (NASDAQ:SHLM), boosted its share price by 1.34, from US$111.62 to US$113.12. One of the world's most diversified technology companies 3M Co (NYSE: MMM) suffered the biggest share price drop, 15.61%, from US$236.48to US$199.56 was due to private investment company Parsons Capital Management Inc reducing its stake by 12.45% in first quarter 2018, despite 3M's good financials in the quarter. Huntsman Corp's (NYSE: HUN) share price dropped by 4.34, followed by PPG Industries (NYSE: PPG) 2.94% and Air Products and Chemicals (NYSE: APD) 0.30% declines. Stock Performances of Leading US Chemical Companies (US$)  Source Mergent analysis Sector Index The FTSE global equity index provides capital growth measurement data for the chemicals industry with mixed review periods and takes into account the ancillary impact the chemicals sector has on the global and North American economies. It showed that the global chemicals segment had a negative total return of 0.87% in the three months under review. This indicated that the chemicals industry weakened over the three months due to the trade dispute between the US and China. The industry had a negative total return of 3.27% year to date June 4, 2018. Stock Performances of Leading Global Financial Services (Total Return)  Source: FTSE Equity Index Based on end-of-day data for the Total Return Index as at June 4, 2018 Leading Companies Robust demand for chemical products, increased efficiency and business expansion saw four leading chemical companies perform well in first quarter 2018, with Praxair having the highest growth, 10%. Although Monsanto had flat growth in the quarter, US chemical companies are likely to continue growing through 2018. DowDupont (NYSE: DWDP) Dow Chemical and DuPont merged on August 31, 2017, forming DowDuPont, the world's largest chemical company. It had a good first quarter 2018, the merger and improved prices and volumes in most segments and regions boosting sales by 5% to US$21.5 billion, from US$20.5 billion in first quarter 2017. In May 2018, DowDuPont announced plans to invest US$45 million to buy and modernize the Delaware plant in Indiana over the next two years. The investment is driven by the increased demand for kalrez sealing materials and the company wants to boost production to meet the demand. In April DowDuPont announced a US$100 million two-year investment to ramp-up manufacturing production and upgrade the Sabine River Works (SRW) plant in Orange County, Texas. DowDuPont will divide into three new companies in second quarter 2019 and the new plant and Corteva Agriscience, the agriculture division of DowDuPont, will be based in Delaware, Indiana. Monsanto Co (NYSE: MON) Agricultural product manufacturer Monsanto's net sales were flat in first quarter 2018, totaling US$2.66 billion, just 0.38% up from US$2.65 billion a year earlier. Gross profit increased by 4% to US$1.31 billion, from US$1.26 billion a year earlier. Monsanto aims to become carbon neutral by 2021 and has reduced its carbon footprint by more than 200,000 metric tonnes, burning 200 million pounds less coal since December 2015. The rate of reduction is expected to increase over the next few years and the company will collaborate with farmers and global partners to educate and encourage them to adopt climate-smart agriculture practices. Monsanto began collaborating with charitable organization 2Blades Foundation in May 2018to produce a genetic solution to Asian soybean rust (ASR). The disease causes soybean leaves to turn yellow and brown, leading to premature senescence and significant yield loss. With a number of effective treatment choices or resistant hybrids accessible, creating new solutions is crucial and the partnership will aid bring much-needed disease-resistance solutions to farmers. PPG Industries Inc (NYSE: PPG) With 90,000 employees in more than 70 countries, multinational conglomerate 3M Co manufactures innovative industrial and consumer products such as abrasives, adhesives, sealants, electronic materials, healthcare and protection products. Its net sales increased to US$3.8 billion in first quarter 2018, up by 9% from US$3.5 billion a year earlier. All business segments grew, industrial coatings the most, by 10%. PPG completed two Colorful Communities projects in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and Istanbul, Turkey, in May. The program, which offers PPG employee volunteers and the company's paint products, along with funds, to bring color and liveliness to communities across the globe, is one of PPG's many community programs. Praxair Inc (NYSE: PX) Industrial gases company Praxair had a strong financial performance in first quarter 2018. Sales grew by 10% from a year earlier to US$3.0 billion, thanks largely to higher volumes in North America, Europe and Asia, and new project start-ups. Volume grew by 4%, driven by rises in North America, Europe and Asia, and operating profit increased by 15% to US$653 million. Praxair announced in May the names of six universities that were awarded the TruForm Ambition Grant introduced in November 2017. The grant supports North American universities involved in metal additive manufacturing (AM) to support sector growth. Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, the University of Pittsburgh and Pennsylvania State University were among the recipients. Mergers, Acquisitions and Joint Ventures Amid favorable market conditions chemical merger and acquisition (M&A) and joint venture activities remained robust in the six months under review. Chemical producers continued to focus on M&A to diversify and increase growth, increasingly seeking opportunities for cost synergies and scale operations through consolidation. Some 195 deals were announced or closed in the American chemicals industry in 2017, 24% down from 2016's h 256 transactions. Public firms maintained their grip on deal share with 70.2% transactions in 2017 and 78.8% of transactions in first quarter 2018 The most notable merger in first quarter 2018 was one of the world's largest plastics companies, Houston-based LyondellBasell Industries' (NYSE: LYB) acquisition of leading global supplier of high-performance plastic compounds A. Schulman (NASDAQ:SHLM) for US$2.25 billion to create an industry-leading compounding business. The acquisition will enhance Lyondell's existing product portfolio and create new product solutions. It will also increase Lyondell's presence in the global market enabling it to meet increased demand. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2018. DowDuPont signed a three-year deal with US-based integrated aerospace and data analytics private firm Planet for an undisclosed amount in March 2018. The collaboration will provide digital agriculture software solutions to growers. It will also upgrade analytics tools and will further aid farmers in controlling risk and optimizing crop yields. This will strength its agriculture business division and help DowDuPont agriculture business and help it to boost crops and reach more customers. German crop-chemical conglomerate Bayer (ETR: BAYN) plans to acquire US-based Monsanto (NYSE: MON) for US$66 billion, creating the world's biggest pesticide and seed company. The proposed deal, expected to close by the end of June, has caused chaos in the agriculture world as the company will control 61% of seeds globally and control pesticide production with the other two mega corporations DowDuPont and ChemChina. Current Environment- Canada Sector Overview The Canadian chemical industry performed well over the six months under review, despite global economic uncertainties and a weakened environment, thanks largely to the abundance of new shale products. Real gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 3% in third quarter 2017 from ayear earlier, thanks to increased household expenditure, higher residential investment, export growth and lower imports. The shale phenomenon continued to generate prospects for long-term availability of cheap natural gas and natural gas liquids, leading to strong industrial chemical performance and stronger investment growth momentum. However, industrial chemical exports were flat in 2017, with 80% of them going to the US, with the next largest importers being China, 7%, and Mexico, 3%. While the shale gas revolution was generally positive for Canadian petrochemical companies, there was a downside, particularly in Alberta, where production was down, because there was less need for the US to import gas from Canada. Lower production means a corresponding reduction in the availability of ethane. This has caused companies in Alberta to look for innovative solutions, such as importing ethane by pipeline from a shale oil formation in North Dakota, extracting more feedstock materials from the by-product. New technologies and advanced materials continue to have enormous commercial potential in Canada. The domestic chemical industry has invested additional funds in R&D and developed infrastructure to create new products and promote them in various markets. The chemical sector should attract further investment through 2018 as its costs are lower than those in many countries and it has the required technical capacity and competence. Alberta's economy is poised to grow as new petrochemical projects worth US$185 billion are being built there, starting in November 2017, the first for almost 30 years. A provincial government royalty tax credit of US$500 million for petrochemical projects is attracting many manufacturers. Other benefits of building in Alberta include ample supplies of low-cost natural gases such as butane, ethane and propane, and lower construction costs. The Canadian Plastics Industry Association (CPIA) and the Chemistry Industry Association of Canada (CIAC) estimate that by 2030, all plastic packaging will be recyclable and economically extracted natural resources, meaning that zero waste will be added to landfills by 2040.That was one recommendations in the ?Towards a Zero Plastic Waste Canada? program proposed by the Canadian Environmental Law Association. Sector Performance The Canadian chemical stock market slipped in the six months under review, with a decline in industrial stocks offsetting stronger resources share prices. Investors were concerned about the US Federal Reserve suggesting a rollback of its monetary stimulus program. They remained cautious and continued to avoid chemical stocks, as declining global growth and a stronger Canadian dollar meant Canadian manufacturing sales remained weak and the trade deficit continued widening. Chemical company share prices on the Toronto Stock Exchange were mixed between January 2 and June 4, 2018, those of five leading companies dropping by an average 6.40%, with only two gainers, Methanex Corp (TSX: MX) and Superior Plus Corp (TSX: SPB). The world's largest producer and supplier of methanol Methanex Corp (TSX: MX) had the biggest gains, with share price growth of 12.06%. This was due to a good first quarter 2018 financial report and rising demand for methane boosting investor confidence, sending share price up from US$61.35 to US$68.75. One of the world's largest wholesale suppliers of oil and gas drilling fluids Bri-Chem Corp (TSX: BRY) was the biggest loser, its share price dropping by 28.57%, from US$0.49 to US$0.35 because of lower drilling fluids sales over the previous quarters. Chemtrade Logistics Income Fund's (TSX: CHE.UN) share price dropped by 15.86%, from US$19.04 to US$16.02, despite good first quarter 2018 financial results. Nutrien's (TSX: NTR) share price declined by 4.18%, from US$50.40 to US$52.60, due to a weak first quarter financial report. Industry Profile - Canada Industry Overview Accounting for 8% of total manufacturing revenues, the C$53 billion (US$38.4 billion) chemical-pharmaceutical industry is key to Canadian innovation and one of the underlying economic pillars supporting major industries. It employs more than 80,000 people and is the fourth largest manufacturing industry by sales after transportation equipment, food and petroleum refining, according to the Chemistry Association of Canada (CIAC). The sector employs 86,700 workers, supports an additional 520,000 jobs and plays an important economic role, the CIAC reports. It transforms and adds value to raw resources such as minerals, crude oil, natural gas and biomass, producing intermediate products used as inputs by other parts of the industry and by almost all other manufacturing sectors. Main consumer industries include oil and gas extraction, pharmaceuticals, plastic and rubber products. The Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development (DFATD) estimates that chemical exports were worth C$18.6 billion (US$14.41 billion) in 2017, the same as in 2016. Of Canada's 3,000 chemical firms, 61% have fewer than 100 employees, while 31% are micro establishments with less than five staffs workers, according to Industry Canada. About 200 establishments are medium sized, employing between 101 and 499 personnel, while 17 companies, with more than 500 employees each, accounted for less than 1% of the total. Thanks largely to investor-friendly policies and rich natural resources, Canada is particularly attractive to global investors. Mergent research found that foreign ownership, predominantly by US and European interests, dominates many medium to large chemical companies, usually through subsidiaries, joint ventures and acquisitions. The largest chemical processing region, Central Canada, has become the engine of the economy and is home to seven of the ten biggest chemical companies, while the major petrochemical manufacturers are based in Western Canada. The industry is concentrated in three provinces: Ontario (44%), Alberta (27%) and Quebec (19%). Ontario has 1,200 chemical plants providing 43,000 high paying jobs and is the largest manufacturer, with exports worth more than C$14 billion (US$10.5 billion) a year. The industry has boomed in Ontario in recent years as the province is in the heart of North America, with easy access to cheap feedstock, biotechnology and nanotechnology. In Alberta, the industry is concentrated in the Fort Saskatchewan and Joffre areas, employing about 9,500 workers directly and supporting 47,000 jobs in the oil and gas, plastics, construction and other sectors. Over the next decade Alberta is likely to invest up to C$5 billion (US$3.7 billion) in the chemical sector. In Quebec, the industry provides more than 15,000 jobs at 350 facilities and employs around 3,000 workers in the relatively small petrochemical segment. Industrial chemicals, which add value to raw materials and act as intermediates for almost all manufacturing industries, are the mainstay of the sector. They are produced in bulk and account for more than half of chemical revenues. Basic chemicals, synthetic resins, rubbers and fibers are categorized as industrial chemicals, the main products including benzene, propylene, ethylene glycol, methanol, styrene, chlorine, sulfuric acid and polyethylene. Exports and Imports The chemical industry is export-driven, with 70% of chemicals produced exported in 2017, 80% of these to the US, followed by China (7%) and Mexico (3%). DFATD estimates that chemical exports totaled C$18.6 billion (US$14.41 billion) in 2017, the same as in 2016. Canada is a net chemical importer because, due to its relatively small domestic market compared with those of China and the US, manufacturers are reluctant to produce chemicals that require a large market to attain economies of scale. As increasing local consumption caused import growth to outpace that of exports the trade deficit widened by 7.3%, from US$26.1 billion in 2016 to US$28 billion in 2017. The minimal trade surplus in industrial chemicals remained highly dependent on external factors, with the ratio of exports to imports ranging between 0.7 and 0.8 over the past decade. Sector Employment The chemical industry employed 90,000 people in 2017 and supported another 520,000 jobs, with 40% working in administration and the remainder in production, according to Industry Canada. The CIAC estimates that one new chemical job generates five positions in other sectors, but the workforce has shrunk by 1.3% a year since 2004. Chemical personnel, among the most specialized and qualified, earned an average C$66,700 (US$51,725) annually, 25% higher than the average manufacturing salary of C$55,100 (US$42,729), in 2017. Industrial chemical salaries were higher, averaging income of CS$81,500 (US$63,203) annually. Chemical industry salaries and wages totaled C$5.4 billion (US$3.92 billion), with C$1.4 billion (US$1.09 billion) paid in the industrial chemical segment. In Ontario, the industry directly employed 44,700 people in 2017, an increase of 1.0% from the previous year. The industry supports around 270,000 jobs in the province and the number in industrial chemicals increased by 5.2% from 2016. Salaries and wages totaled C$3 billion (US$2.3 billion), an annual average of C$68,100 (US$52,811), while the industrial chemicals average annual income was C$81,800 (C$63,436). The average salary across all manufacturing industries in Ontario was C$58,800 (US$45,600). In Alberta, the industry employed 7,600 people in 2017, down by 7% from 2016, and supported around 45,000 jobs, with the number of employees in industrial chemicals totaling 3,970. In Quebec, the industry employed 22,600 workers and supported 135,000 jobs, with industrial chemicals employing 3,400 people. Capital Expenditure and Intensity of Canadian Chemical Companies  Source: Mergent analysis Policy and Regulatory Environment Canada is among world leaders in chemical regulation and has formulated a Chemicals Management Plan (CMP), not only to support the Strategic Approach to International Chemical Management (SAICM) but also to realize goals set by the World Summit on Sustainable Development for Chemicals by 2020. The Canada Consumer Product Safety Act (CCPSA), Pest Control Products Act (PCPA) and Food and Drugs Act (F&DA) are the major legislation used to implement the CMP. Under the Canada Environmental Protection Act (CEPA) 1999, the primary federal chemical legislation jointly administered by Environment Canada (EC) and Health Canada (HC), new chemical products must be submitted for safety evaluation before commercialization and all chemicals used in Canada must be registered on the Domestic Substances List. In 2006, 4,300 substances with potential persistent toxic effects were screened for further assessment through a categorization process. A CMP status report in June 2017 found that around 3,200 of the 4,300 substances requiring further attention were assessed and 420 substances were found to be toxic. The Canadian Government announced in October 2017 that the Environmental Protection Act 1999 (CEPA) and the Chemicals Management Plan (CMP) would be modernized and improved. The complete proposal for a revised CEPA was to be submitted by June 2018. A risk-based approach is used to regulate CEPA-toxic substances, with a variety of tools applied to evaluate and manage potential risks. The Government has the right to control the use of chemicals on the List of Toxic Substances through restriction or prohibition of use and release, prevention notices, codes of practice and public engagement, in addition to introducing voluntary self-regulation to minimize negative consequences. In May 2018, the Canadian Government proposed clearing cumene hydroperoxide and dicumyl peroxide as safe to be used under section 64 of CEPA. Cumene hydroperoxide is used widely in commercial products such as building and construction materials, and dicumyl peroxide is used in building and construction materials, in plastic and rubber materials, and in products used in automotive, aircraft and transportation applications. The Government expects to issue a final assessment in May 2019. More effective regulatory measures were introduced, benefitting Canadian chemical companies by lowering regulatory barriers, through the cross-border Canada-US Regulatory Cooperation Council (RCC) Initiative, which emphasizes chemical management, Environment Canada (EC), Health Canada (HC) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have developed work plans on new uses of chemical substances and risk assessment to facilitate information collection and sharing, technical and scientific partnership, and risk evaluation methods. In addition to a tariff-free-zone for industrial manufacturers the Canadian Government has implemented a duty-free manufacturing tariff regime. The initiative has been largely welcomed by the industry for reducing costs, enhancing productivity, promoting innovation and increasing foreign investment inflow. However, smaller domestic producers say that they are losing out as intensified competition squeezes their profit margins. Industry Profile - US Industry Overview With chemical products used as intermediates for more than 96% of all manufactured goods, according to the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the US chemical industry is a key to improving living standards. Its development is associated closely with several macroeconomic and external factors, including economic development of major trading partners, monetary policies, exchange rates, geopolitical issues, commodity prices, the performance of manufacturing sectors and other key end-user markets such as automotive and construction. It is one of largest manufacturing sectors in the country with more than 10,000 companies employing 811,000 people and manufacturing more than 70,000 products to meet domestic and global demand. Its US$800 billion revenue accounted for 15% of the world total in 2016, according to the ACC, second only to that of China. Sales to end-use markets constituted 49% of total turnover, while intra-industry sales, such as that of ethylene to manufacture plastics, made up the remainder. Rubber and plastics was the biggest chemical-consuming sector, using US$76.1 billion worth of chemical products in 2016, followed by healthcare, agriculture and other manufacturing sectors, according to the ACC. Other main downstream industries included metals, energy, construction, food and beverage, electronics, machinery, construction, transportation, paper, textiles and apparel. The US is well known globally for its pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals, plastic resins and specialty chemicals. The sector is a vital pillar of the economy and has added more than US$300 billion, or more than 2%, to GDP annually since 2009, the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) estimates. Chemical shipments, including pharmaceuticals, US$788.3 billion in 2017, accounting for 16% of US exports, according to the ACC. The development of shale gas resources has changed the competitive landscape of the entire industry, which utilizes more gas-based feedstock than the oil-based feedstock commonly used by European and Asian manufacturers. This has enabled the country not only to transform itself from a high-cost to low-cost chemical maker but also to attract investment to avoid losing ground globally. With energy and feedstock prices remaining low the sector continues to attract local and overseas investors, with around 325 new chemical production projects nationwide as of April 2018, according to the ACC. These projects, 60% of which are foreign direct investment (FDI), have a combined value of more than US$194 billion. Investment in chemical and plastics manufacturing capacity is worth more than US$130 billion in 2017, ACC figures show. The US is expected to become a natural gas net exporter by 2018. Chemical investment is forecast to grow and exceed consumer spending as a driver of the US economy. The ACC estimates that, excluding pharmaceuticals, chemical capacity will grow 4.2% in 2018 and 4.1 in 2019. The agency estimates that capital spending will increase by more than 6% to US$35.7 billion in 2018. The US Census Bureau divides chemical shipments into four segments: pesticides and fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals and chemicals used in paints, coatings and adhesives. US chemical shipments in January 2018 increased slightly 0.18% from a year earlier from US67.94 billion to US$68.06 billion according to the US Department of Commerce. Chemicals were the third largest non-durable goods industry in the US, behind transportation equipment's US$81.47 billion and food products' US$68.78 billion. Policy and Regulatory Environment The US is gradually amending its chemical regulations to reduce the adverse impact of chemical use and production after the European Union's (EU) implementation of the Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH). Critics have long regarded the 1976 Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), administered by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), as heavily flawed and ineffective in controlling industrial chemicals, as it has not been updated for almost 40 years. Certain fundamental weaknesses of the act, including chemical commercialization without pre-market safety reviews and labeling, and resting the burden of proof of safety on the EPA instead of chemical companies, have caused many states to intervene by introducing stricter local policies. The TSCA issued three final framework rules in June 2017, published one year after the amended Frank R. Lautenberg Chemical Safety for the 21stCentury Act was signed into law. The statutory deadline for actions must be completed within a year of the law's passage. The three rules are: the EPA should prioritize existing chemicals for evaluating their risks, the EPA will evaluate the risk posed by existing substances and the EPA will label substances on the TSCA inventory as active or inactive. As of April 2018, the EPA figures show the latest inventory contains 86,303 chemical substances which 38,303 substances are active and 48,000 have not been reported as active. 30,972 of active substances are on the public inventory and 7,331 on the confidential inventory. The EPA also notes there are over 100 pending proposed chemical regulations. The most popular proposed chemical regulations are related to limiting exposure to polyfluoroalkyl substances and flame retardants. Perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances are highly fluorinated chemicals and studies by the EPA show that these substances when exposed are harmful to humans. These substances are widely used especially in everyday life, thus the EPA wants to reduce the use of these substances. CAPP analyzes key oil and gas issues and represents member interests nationally in 12 of Canada's 13 provinces and territories. Chemistry Industry Association of Canada (CIAC) The association represents Canada's leading petrochemicals, inorganic and specialty chemicals producers, bio-based manufacturers, chemistry-related technology and R&D companies. Export Development Canada (EDC) The EDC provides trade finance and risk management services for Canadian exporters and investors. Industry Canada A government department that promotes investment and trade and provides information about Canadian industries. Statistics Canada Statistics Canada is a national agency that provides official Canadian social and economic statistics and products. Market Trends & Outlook US Petrochemical Plants Fuel Ethane Consumption and Exports Within the next two years, ethane consumption by the US petrochemical industry will surpass the combined consumption of all other petroleum and liquid products, the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) estimates. The agency also forecast that ethane exports will continue to grow as the number of ethane pipelines and export terminals increases. Ethane is a crucial substance, used as a feedstock for ethylene, the base for most plastics, resins and other industrial products. The rapid expansion of plastics and petrochemical plants along the Texas Gulf Coast is responsible for the growth of ethane consumption. Three Gulf Coast ethylene crackers opened in 2017, boosting domestic ethane consumption by 210,000 barrels a day (b/d) to 1.2 billion b/d, according to the EIA. It anticipates that ethylene plant volume will continue to increase as six ethylene crackers, to be completed by the end of 2019, will together consume 380,000 barrels a day (b/d) of ethane. The agency expects the annual consumption of ethane to surge to 1.4 million in 2018 and 1.6 million b/d in 2019. There are many major projects under construction, including French oil major Total SA's (EPA: FP) planned US$1.7 billion ethane steam cracker alongside its Port Arthur, Texas, refinery, part of a joint venture with Austrian and Canadian private companies Borealis AG and Nova Chemicals Corp. Exxon Mobil (NYSE: XOM) plans to start up a new cracker at its Baytown complex, the largest petrochemical complex in the US, in first half 2018, to produce 1.5 million tons of ethylene annually. The EIA expects average annual exports to grow from 180,000 b/d in 2017 to 290,000 b/d in 2018 and 310,000 b/d in 2019. US-based natural gas pipeline transportation company Kinder Morgan's (NYSE: KMI) Utopia pipeline started transporting ethane from Ohio's Utica shale field to Canada in January 2018 and this is expected to drive part of US ethane growth. Ethane shipments from two terminals: Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania, and Morgan's Point, Texas, which started in 2016, supply petrochemical feedstock by tanker to countries such as Brazil and Sweden, and the EIA expects them to extend shipments to China in fourth quarter 2019. US-China Trade War Will Affect US Chemicals Industry Free trade has been a driver of the US chemical industry but a looming the trade war with China is a major concern, according to American Fuels and Petrochemicals Manufacturers (AFPM). President Trump announced in April 2018 that the US would impose tariffs on 1,300 Chinese products valued at US$$60 billion, of which 40% are chemicals, and will restrict Chinese investment in the US to punish China for alleged technology and trade-secret theft. In response China announced plans to raise tariffs on 128 US goods, including 44 chemical products. However, a late-May pledge by China to import more US products could avert a feared trade war, which would negatively affect the industry. China is the third biggest chemical exporter to the US, with shipments valued at US$10.6 billion in 2016, the latest year included in an American Chemical Council (ACC) analysis of US Department of Commerce data. The agency reported that China imported 11%, or US$3.2 billion worth, of all US plastic resins in 2017 and that the US exported chemicals and polymers worth US$11.5 billion, or 9% of its overall chemical exports, to China in 2017. US chemicals on which China could imposed tariffs include low-density polyethylene (LDPE), polyolefin elastomers and plastomers (POEs, POPs), polyvinyl chloride (PVC) resin and polycarbonate. The US exported more than 152,000 tonnes of LDPE worth US$$215 million and over 129,000 tonnes of polycarbonate worth US$$325 million to China in 2016. Investment worth US$185 billion to build new chemical factories in the US and expand and restart facilities around the country is predicated on current tariff schedules. A trade war with China would jeopardize these projects as market shifts caused by tariff increases could convince investors to do business elsewhere. Chinese tariffs would make US chemical firms unsure about selling their surplus products on the international market. Some major companies have raised the prices of their chemical products due to concerns over a trade war. Chemical Spending Surges Access to cheaper and more abundant feedstock and energy is a big advantage to American chemical manufacturers, increasing the number of chemical production projects to 320 worth more than US$185 billion, according to the American Chemistry Council (ACC). In addition to the new projects, industry capital spending totaled US$38 billion in 2017, accounting for half of total construction spending by the whole manufacturing sector. According to the agency, capital spending increased by 6% in 2017 and forecasts 6.3% growth in 2018 and 6.9% 2019, the total to reach US$48 billion by 2022. The country remains one of the leading destinations for chemical investment due to its cheap, abundant feedstock, with 62% of the US$185 billion in announced projects being foreign direct investment. Petrochemicals will dominate capital spending in the US chemical industry, the ACC forecasting that petrochemical capital investment will grow by 7% to US$8.6 billion in 2018, with major capacity additions, as the industry recovers from Hurricane Harvey-related disruptions and continues delayed projects. Chemical industry capital spending rose by 67% in seven years to $33.8 billion in 2017, the chemical sector accounting for half of manufacturing sector construction spending, according to the ACC. Industry capital spending in the US is expected to total US$48 billion in 2018, nearly two-and-a-half times the level in 2010, thanks largely to the shale boom. Planned plant turnarounds, shutdowns and outages rose by 5% in 2017, mostly in the refining industry according to the ACC. As demand for US feedstock remains high, primarily in overseas markets, refiners are likely to increase planned maintenance expenditure by 38.5% to US$1.26 billion in 2018. US tax reform, signed in December 2017, is expected to boost chemical capital investment. The reform reduced corporate tax from 35% to 21% and allows companies to claim 100% rebate on certain capital expenditure for the first five years. This should boost investment in major chemical projects. Market Outlook The threatened trade war between China and the US is casting a cloud over the US chemical industry. Nevertheless, it is poised to grow thanks to the benefits of shale gas, surging capital investment, continuous product innovation and the strengthening domestic economy. Chemical companies will continue taking advantage of abundant supplies of shale gas and its related products. Global markets are expected to improve as increased consumer confidence and improved employment conditions will continue to support sector growth, especially due to increasing automotive manufacturing and construction activities. The ACC says that US chemical production will increase in 2018 amid robust demand, especially for shale-related chemicals in domestic and overseas markets, and increased investment due to promising markets and capacity additions. However, a stronger dollar will hamper exports and make US chemicals less attractive in international markets, but strength in US manufacturing is providing a significant boost for chemical demand from end-users and is improving the job market. Market Trends & Outlook Canada Chemical Industry Essential for Low Carbon Economy Canada introduced the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change in January 2018, the Government's plan to meet its emissions reduction targets and create a clean economy. It aims to boost innovation and growth by encouraging technology development and adoption to make sure Canadian companies are competitive in the global low-carbon economy. It also includes actions to enhance climate change adaptation and build resilience to climate effects. The sector plays a major part in dealing with climate change globally. Canada has plentiful, low carbon resources, including natural gas and natural gas liquid, which are chemical feedstocks. More than 95% of all manufactured products depend on the chemical industry, without which advances in key industries, including green buildings, sustainable transportation, clean energy and sustainable agriculture would have not happened. The Canadian industry has been a leader in and shown its commitment to responsible and sustainable chemical manufacturing for more than two decades. The Chemistry Industry Association of Canada (CIAC) established an initiative, ?Responsible Care?, in 1985 and more than 62 countries have adopted it, pledging to fight climate change by reducing emissions from their facilities and making their products ?greener?. More and more countries are beginning to follow these practices as they recognize the importance of fighting climate change. Chemical manufacturing contributes less than 2% of Canada's national greenhouse gas emissions thanks to support from the Government and a commitment to innovation. The sector recognizes its role as an emitter of greenhouse gases and a climate change solutions provider. One of the goals of the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change, is to put a price on carbon pollution by the end of 2018. The Government wants it to start at US$10 a tonne, rising by US$10 a year to US$50 a tonne in 2022. With government support and the right policies the chemical industry could attract more than US$25 billion in new investment by 2025. This will not only stimulate economic growth and drive innovation but also influence the contribution that the industry makes in meeting rapidly growing worldwide market demand for chemicals with the lowest carbon emissions. Sustainable Chemistry Boosts Ontario Investment People are becoming more concerned about the environment and government urging and consumer demand for sustainable processes have pushed chemical manufacturers to shift to greener chemicals. This has become a priority as they seek to reduce negative impacts on the environment and ensure that their chemicals are safe for consumers. Sarnia-Lambton in Ontario, known as Chemical Valley, has been a petrochemical industry hub for more than seven decades, home to more than 60 chemical facilities and oil refineries. It is attracting green investment with the help of the Government, which provides incentives for chemical companies to build plants. Bioindustrial Innovation Canada (BIC), a Sarnia-based, not-for-profit institution, aims to help Ontario and Canada become global leaders in sustainable chemistry. The BIC and GreenCentre Canada announced in May 2018 that they will invest an undisclosed amount into waste water treatment services company Forward Water Technologies This will help the company to develop a commercial scale-up of a proprietary forward osmosis technology, allowing it to meet the rising global demand for fresh water and significantly cut wastewater treatment and disposal costs. It is expected to come online in 2022. BIC approved an unspecified investment in Texas-based private biodiesel company Benefuel Inc in May 2018. Benefuel plans to build refining plants, the first of which will produce 75-million liters of biodiesel a year, Production is likely to start in 2020 and a second project will double output. These projects will boost employment and spur economic growth in Ontario. Advance Chemical Technologies announced that is collaborating with private, California-based bio chemical company Origin Materials to build the second largest plana plant in Sarnia. It will produce polymers and other products from bio-based materials and should be operational in 2020. British Columbia-based private biochemical company S2G Biochemicals Inc plans to build a US$20 billion bio-chemical facility in Sarnia, with construction starting in 2018 and expected to be completed in 2020. It will produce 2,000 tonnes of the sweetener xylitol annually and bio-glycols from agricultural residues. London-based private biorefining and biomass company Comet Biorefining Inc plans to build a US$70 million plant in Sarnia, expected to come online in 2019. Comet's cellulosic dextrose innovation transforms non-food biomass, including agricultural and forest material, into high-purity dextrose. This has renewable biochemical and biofuel applications, such as replacing petroleum-based products in a range of industries. Western Canadian Liquefied Natural Gas Exports Surge Canada has ample natural gas deposits and, with global demand for natural gas expected to rise by 46% by 2040, there is a huge opportunity to exploit its resources. The Pacific North West LNG project is a major opportunity to strengthen the economy, creating 4,500 direct and 630 indirect jobs. Local First Nation communities will benefit significantly through agreements reached with the developer. The project will transport 19 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas (LNG) annually through the TransCanada pipeline to Lelu Island near Prince Rupert for export to Asia. The British Columbia Government estimates that LNG exports will rise to 2.2 billion cubic feet a day (Bcf/d) in 2020, from 1.6 billion cubic feet, and increase to 3.4 Bcf/d in 2032. LNG Canada, a partnership between four major natural gas companies with substantial experience in LNG: Royal Dutch Shell (AMS: RDSA), Korea Gas Corp (KRX: 036460), Mitsubishi Corp (TYO: 8058) and PetroChina (SHA: 601857), will build and operate an LNG export terminal at Kitimat, on British Columbia's northwest coast. Costing US$40 billion, it is the largest single infrastructure investment in BC's history Construction will begin in 2018 and is expected to be completed by 2027. TransCanada Corp will start construction of its US$4.7 billion Coastal Gaslink pipeline in early 2019. It will transport 5 Bcf/d of LNG from Alberta and northeast BC to a terminal near Kitimat for overseas shipment. The BC Government introduced new conditions and tax subsidies for the province's LNG projects in March 2018. They should attract more LNG investment in Western Canada and the Coastal Gaslink pipeline will bolster Western Canadian LNG exports. The pipeline will have a total capacity of six million tonnes of LNG a year, surging to 26 million tonnes through future expansion. Market Outlook The Canadian chemical industry is expected to grow by 27% through to 2020, according to the CIAC. Many companies are increasing investment and merging or expanding operations to stay competitive in the global market. Exports will continue to grow, as will demand for oil and gas production in North America, meaning more pipelines and other infrastructures projects. The growth of value-added industries related to resource development should expand the Canadian economy and benefit many sectors, including the chemical industry, bringing stable, high-paying jobs over the next 20 years. Canada has ample natural resources and a diversified economy with a variety of services and manufacturing. Rising business investment, driven by strong corporate balance sheets and a high level of foreign direct investment, should help raise production capacity. New shale gas and biomass feedstock, and a growing market for chemical-based solutions, place the chemical sector in a good position for growth. By working with the Federal Government to boost competitiveness, the industry should continue to see growth and environmental benefits. title: FCC says its software keeps farm data confidential
article: Farmers using Farm Credit Canada's AgExpert software have independent assurance their business data isn't accessible to unauthorized users, says Fred Wall, the corporation's vice-president for marketing. The AgExpert software has been certified by Ag Data Transparent (ADT), a U.S.-based, notfor-profit company, which verifies the security of agricultural data gathered by firms working with farmers. "Transparency and integrity are fundamental to what we do," Wall said. "We want our customers, the producers, to know we are taking this seriously. Third-party verification shows they can trust us with their information. "The ADT process is solid and simple, just like our software," he said. "It tells our producers exactly how we handle their data, what we do with it and who has access to it. Data transparency is top of mind for our customers and it's a priority for us." The ADT certification means FCC is committed to industrywide principles, including transparency in data collection, access, use, portability, availability and retention, he said. FCC has become the first Canadian company to receive the ADT seal for its commitment to safeguarding farmers' data. FCC recently released its web-based version AgExpert Field, which enables producers to record, share and analyze field data, such as inputs, yields and field conditions -right from their mobile phone. It plans to soon launch a webbased version of it farm financial software, AgExpert Accounting. "Grain Farmers of Ontario thinks this is a great first step for the industry in Canada and we recognize the importance of accreditations like ADT for services and products that collect farmer and farm data," said GFO spokeswoman Victoria Berry. "We would congratulate FCC for achieving this." ADT administrator Todd Janzen said, "All the companies and organizations that designed Ag Data Transparent understood the need for transparency and trust in the ag precision sector." "They knew that data and analysis will continue to change and improve agriculture, but that the producer deserves to work with credible data partners. "Certification shows a commitment to the producers, the backbone of the ag industry," he said. ADT represents a coalition of major farm organizations, commodity groups and agriculture technology providers. The ADT Evaluator was created to help producers understand where their data is going, who has access and control over it. ADT works to protect farmers in today's big-data market, he said. "Only companies that meet all core principles regarding collection, access and ownership are awarded the certified seal." Guelph-based Canada Digital Agri-Food (CDAF), which is working to help farmers take full advantage of the Big Data era, welcomed FCC's certification. "For ag-tech companies, the ADT process requires considerable commitment in terms of time and resources," said CDAF Director Karen Hand. "As the first Canadian company to become ADT certified, FCC exemplifies incredible leadership in demonstrating their commitment to Canadian farmers as a farm-first organization -a value shared across the Canadian ag-tech landscape." CDAF's role is to help the agrifood sector make full use of the emergence of digital technology and precision farming. "The ability of the Canadian agrifood sector to commit to the establishment of a comprehensive digital transformation strategy will determine our future as either leaders or followers in the global marketplace," it said. "Through the development, implementation and operation of open, shared tools and platforms CDAF can equip Ontario farmers with decision support tools relevant to their farms," it said. "CDAF will all enable participants to take advantage of builtin-Canada solutions designed to support them in the highly competitive global economy in which we operate."

title: Technology - Agricultural Technology; Reports from University of Guelph Describe Recent Advances in Agricultural Technology (Characterizing soil particle sizes using wavelet analysis of microscope images)
article: 2018 JUN 7 (VerticalNews) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Week -- Investigators publish new report on Technology - Agricultural Technology. According to news reporting originating in Guelph, Canada, by VerticalNews journalists, research stated, "Soil texture (relative proportions of soil particles of varied sizes) is a fundamental soil physical property affecting almost all other soil physical properties and processes of agricultural, environmental and engineering importance. However, characterization of particle sizes in the laboratory presents a range of challenges in terms of the time, labor, difficulty and/or cost involved with the analysis." Funders for this research include NSERC Discovery, McGill Precision Agriculture and Sensor Systems Research Team. The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the University of Guelph, "Continuous wavelet transform (CWT) has been used in characterizing scale-specific variations in spatial or temporal domain as well as in image analysis. The objective of this study was to develop a CWT-based computer vision algorithm to characterize soil particle sizes from digital images captured with a microscope. A cheap portable microscope with 5 MP camera and maximum magnification of 200 x was used to develop an image acquisition system. Three images of air-dried, ground (2 mm) soil samples were captured in laboratory conditions for each soil sample (56 + 67 = 123) collected from two agricultural fields (Field26 and Field86) with highly variable soils. Triplicate in-situ images were also collected from 67 locations from Field86 after scrapping off surface residues. The color images were transferred to grey-scale images and the CWT was performed along the 20 equally-spaced rows and columns. The total area under the average global wavelet spectrum represented the total variation in any image. Two fractions of particle sizes; 'coarse' (diameter between 2.0 mm and 0.05 mm) and 'fine' (diameter < 0.05 mm), respectively, representing sand and sum of silt and clay were calculated based on the area under the curve and compared with lab-measured particle sizes using the hydrometer method. The lab-measured coarse- and fine-fractions showed strong agreement with the predicted (from image) fractions. The regression relationship showed the prediction capability of 87% and 88% for coarse (RMSE 44.7 g kg(-1)) and fine (RMSE 44.7 g kg(-1)) fractions, respectively for Field26 samples. A similar prediction was obtained (88% with RMSE 40.2 g kg(-1) for coarse and 88% with RMSE 40.3 g kg(-1) for fine) for Field86 samples. The efficiency of the wavelet algorithm shows promise in determining the particle sizes from an image and the portable nature of the image acquisition system results in a good proximal soil sensor." According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "In contrast to the laboratory images, a weak prediction (48% for coarse and 56% for fine) was observed for the images taken in-situ mainly due to the quality of the images as they were affected by various field conditions; this requires further research." Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting A. Biswas, University of Guelph, Sch Environm Sci, Guelph, ON N1G 2W1, Canada. Additional authors for this research include W.J. Ji, V. Adamchuk and B. Sudarsan. Keywords for this news article include: Guelph, Ontario, Canada, North and Central America, Agricultural Technology, Technology, Agricultural, Agriculture, University of Guelph. Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2018, NewsRx LLC

title: MIL-OSI Canada: Competition and innovation safeguarded in the Canadian agricultural sector
article: Source: Government of Canada - MIL OSI National News Competition Bureau reaches consent agreement with Bayer in its proposed acquisition of Monsanto May 30, 2018 - OTTAWA, ON - Competition Bureau The Competition Bureau announced today that it has reached an agreement with Bayer AG (Bayer) related to its proposed acquisition of Monsanto Company (Monsanto). This agreement addresses the Commissioner of Competition's concerns that the proposed transaction would have significantly harmed competition and innovation in Canada's agricultural sector. Following an extensive review, the Bureau concluded that the proposed acquisition would likely substantially lessen and prevent competition in Canada with respect to the supply of canola seeds and traits, soybean seeds and traits, seed treatments that protect crops against nematodes, and carrot seeds. To address those concerns, the agreement requires Bayer to sell its canola seed and traits business, soybean seed and traits business, carrot seed business, nematode seed treatment business, glufosinate-ammonium herbicide business, LibertyLink herbicide tolerance technology, assets related to the Centurion herbicide, and digital farming business in Canada. Bayer has proposed BASF SE as the buyer of the assets under the agreement. The Bureau is actively reviewing the suitability of BASF as the proposed buyer of these assets. The Bureau is satisfied that the agreement will preserve competition and innovation in important agricultural inputs such as canola seeds, Canada's highest acreage crop. Given that Bayer and Monsanto's businesses operate in many countries and the global nature of the transaction, the Bureau coordinated its review with other jurisdictions, including the European Commission and the U.S. Department of Justice (U.S. DOJ). The Bureau's strong relationships with the European Commission and the U.S. DOJ resulted in an efficient review of this matter. The Bureau will publish a comprehensive position statement on its review in the coming days. Quotes "Agriculture has always been a critical part of the Canadian economy, and innovation remains as important in this industry as in emerging sectors. This agreement with Bayer will protect competition and innovation in Canada's agricultural sector, and is the result of a collaborative approach with the parties and our international counterparts." John Pecman Commissioner of Competition Quick facts * On September 14, 2016, Bayer and Monsanto signed a definitive agreement under which Bayer proposed to acquire Monsanto for US$128 per share. The offer price valued Monsanto at US$66 billion. * Bayer is a global pharmaceutical, consumer health, animal health and crop protection science company headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany. * Monsanto is a global provider of agricultural products headquartered in St. Louis, Missouri. * Bayer's LibertyLink herbicide tolerance trait can be found in approximately 55% of canola seeds sold in Canada and Monsanto's Roundup Ready trait can be found in approximately 40% of these seeds. * According to the Canola Council of Canada, the canola industry contributes $26.7 billion per year to the Canadian economy. title: EUO Eurocontrol loses $1.75-million in Q1 2018
article: Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc (TSX-V:EUO) Shares Issued 90,750,238 Last Close 5/30/2018 $0.08 Wednesday May 30 2018 - News Release An anonymous director reports EUROCONTROL REPORTS FIRST QUARTER 2018 RESULTS Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. has filed its interim financial statements, and management's discussion and analysis (MD&A) for the first quarter ended March 31, 2018. The first quarter results reflect a 38% decrease in first quarter revenue to $348,317 compared to $560,248 for the interim period ended March 31, 2017. The Company recognized EBITDA of ($1,839,527) ($1,565,799 in 2017) resulting in a net loss of $1,751,345 for the quarter compared to a net loss of $1,378,799 for the three month period ended March 31, 2017. As part of the previously announced strategic review process that is being overseen by a special committee of independent directors of the Company, steps have been implemented to reduce staffing levels at the Company's subsidiary companies, Xenemetrix, Croptimal and XwinSys, located in Israel. The Company's board of directors is continuing to consider and evaluate strategic alternatives and is evaluating potential investment opportunities that will enhance the Company's growth profile and future profitability. There is no assurance that the review by the Company's board of directors will result in a transaction or other strategic alternative and the board has not set a timetable for the completion of the review process. About Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. Eurocontrol is a TSX Venture and OTCQB traded company that has three wholly owned subsidiaries, Xenemetrix Ltd., XwinSys Technology Development Ltd. and Croptimal Ltd. Xenemetrix designs, manufacturers and markets ED-XRF systems, a technology that is the most accurate and economic method for determining the chemical composition of many types of materials, including the analysis of petroleum oils and fuel. XwinSys has developed a patented, fully automated metrology system for the semiconductor industry that combines 2D and 3D image processing technology with Xenemetrix's ED-XRF technology. Croptimal, is introducing a new mobile ED-XRF spectroscopic material analysis laboratory for the precision agriculture industry. We seek Safe Harbor.
